title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines "article of fur" and "interstate or foreign commerce" and clarifies the term "import" in relation to fur products. The term "interstate or foreign commerce" is defined in relation to fur products as per section 10 of title 18, United States Code. The term "import" refers to bringing goods into the United States, regardless of customs laws. The term "person" includes various entities subject to US jurisdiction. The term "Secretary" specifically refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" refers to a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "Secretary" specifically means the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. No fur article can be imported, exported, or shipped if derived from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or receive fur in violation of this rule, transport steel jaw leghold traps, or purchase traps in violation of regulations. Penalties apply for knowingly violating these rules. Any person who knowingly violates regulations regarding the import, export, or transportation of fur articles derived from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps may face fines up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and imprisonment for subsequent violations. SEC. 4. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, and seize packages and make arrests without a warrant for violations. The Act allows individuals to detain, search, and seize packages, make arrests without a warrant, and enforce warrants issued by judges or magistrates. Seized items are held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. Any item seized under this Act shall be held by an authorized person pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions. The Secretary may allow the owner to post a bond. Forfeited items will be disposed of as prescribed by the Secretary. Fur or steel jaw leghold traps taken contrary to the Act will face penalties. The Secretary may prescribe regulations for the enforcement of this Act. Any fur or steel jaw leghold trap in violation of the Act may be forfeited to the United States. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators. The Secretary will establish regulations to enforce the Act, which will take effect one year after its enactment.
